issues.text: Whether the accused had prepared false documents and committed criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs. 369.07

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above, we find no cogent ground to disagree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused had prepared false documents and had also committed criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs. 369.07.

issues.text: Whether the accused were in the discharge of their duties guilty of criminal misconduct as defined in section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: We also agree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused were in the discharge of their duties guilty of criminal misconduct as defined in section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

issues.text: Whether completion of rectification work and disbursement after March 11, 1966 but before detection absolves the accused of liability for preparing false documents and misappropriation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kotwal has argued that the accused completed the recti- fication work after May 11, 1966,. There is, however, no direct evidence as may show that the, rectification work was completed after May 11, 1966. Even if it may be assumed that the accused completed the rectification work in May 1966, that fact, in our opinion, would no absolve the accused of their criminal liability. The charge, against the accused relates to preparation of false documents because even though no work had been done till March 11, 1966 and no amount had been disbursed, they prepared docu- ments showing the doing of that work and the payment of that amount. It is no answer to, that charge that after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities, the accused in the month of May 1966 got the rectification work done. It is also no answer to a charge of criminal misappropriation that the money was subsequently, after the matter had been reported to the high authorities, disbursed for the purpose for which it had been entrusted. According to explanation 1 to section 403 Indian Penal Code, a dishonest misappropriation for a time only is misappropriation within the meaning of that section.

issues.text: Whether the investigation was conducted in breach of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act and if so, whether it vitiates the trial and conviction

anchor.surface_text: Argument has then been advanced on behalf of the appellants that Sub Inspector Patil did no make investigation in the case in accordance with law. It is urged that permission to make investigation was granted to Sub Inspector Patil on November 12, 1966 and, as such, he was no authorized to make before that date the enquiry which led to the registration of the case as that enquiry partook of the character of investigation. Nothing has been brought to our notice as to how an enquiry before the registration of a case can be held to be investigation. The matter, however, need no be dilated upon and it is no necessary to express any final opinion in the matter because we find that there is no material on the record as may show that the accused were prejudiced because of the alleged no-compliance with the provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act. It is well established that where cognizance of a case has, in fact, been taken by the court on a police report following investigation conducted in breach of provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act, the result of the trial cannot be set aside unless the illegality in the investigation can be shown to have brought about a miscarriage of justice.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution is barred by section 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act, 1942

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Kotwal that the prosecution of the accused was barred by time under section 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes, Act, 1942. The section reads as under No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act or the rules made thereunder. No suit or prosecution shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything done or intended to be done, under this Act, unless the, suit or prosecution has been instituted within six months from the date of the act complained of.

arguments.claim: The accused expressed willingness to complete the work after the matter was reported, which exonerates them.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kotwal has also submitted that the accused expressed willingness to complete the work after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities. This submission, even if accepted, would no exonerate the accused because the willingness after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities could no efface or undo the offence earlier committed by the accused.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the above, we find no cogent ground to disagree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused had prepared false documents and had also committed criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs. 369.07.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preparation of false documents and criminal breach of trust in official duties constitutes criminal misconduct; agrees with lower courts.

holdings.text: Even if assumed accused completed rectification work in May 1966, that does not absolve criminal liability for preparing false documents on March 11, 1966 and temporary misappropriation; dishonest misappropriation for a time only is misappropriation per Explanation 1 to IPC s403.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kotwal has argued that the accused completed the recti- fication work after May 11, 1966,. There is, however, no direct evidence as may show that the, rectification work was completed after May 11, 1966. Even if it may be assumed that the accused completed the rectification work in May 1966, that fact, in our opinion, would no absolve the accused of their criminal liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No direct evidence of later completion; false documents prepared when no work done; subsequent work or disbursement does not undo offence; applies IPC s403 Expl1.

holdings.text: Alleged non-compliance with s5A Prevention of Corruption Act in investigation does not vitiate trial or conviction absent miscarriage of justice or prejudice to accused.

anchor.surface_text: Argument has then been advanced on behalf of the appellants that Sub Inspector Patil did no make investigation in the case in accordance with law. It is urged that permission to make investigation was granted to Sub Inspector Patil on November 12, 1966 and, as such, he was no authorized to make before that date the enquiry which led to the registration of the case as that enquiry partook of the character of investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-registration enquiry not investigation; no material showing prejudice; follows H.N. Rishbud v. State of Delhi that investigation illegality does not affect trial competence unless miscarriage of justice.

holdings.text: Prosecution not barred by s23 Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act: acts not in good faith (not honest) so s23(1) inapplicable; acts not done under the Act but in breach thereof so s23(2) inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Kotwal that the prosecution of the accused was barred by time under section 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes, Act, 1942. The section reads as under No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act or the rules made thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants not honest per Bombay General Clauses Act definition of good faith; impugned acts (false documents, breach of trust) in flagrant breach, not under the Act.

precedents.case_name: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: illegality committed in the course of investigation does not affect the competence and jurisdiction of the court to try the accused and does not vitiate the conviction unless it has caused prejudice to the accused or miscarriage of justice

anchor.surface_text: We have heard Mr. Kotwal on behalf of the, appellants and are of the opinion that there is numbermerit in the appeal. It has number been disrupted before us that the accused made various entries and prepared documents on March 11, 1966 about their having got the rectification work done as well as about the payment of Rs. 369.07 on that account.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Kotwal has argued that the accused completed the recti- fication work after May 11, 1966,. There is, however, no direct evidence as may show that the, rectification work was completed after May 11, 1966. Even if it may be assumed that the accused completed the rectification work in May 1966, that fact, in our opinion, would no absolve the accused of their criminal liability.

anchor.surface_text: Argument has then been advanced on behalf of the appellants that Sub Inspector Patil did no make investigation in the case in accordance with law. It is urged that permission to make investigation was granted to Sub Inspector Patil on November 12, 1966 and, as such, he was no authorized to make before that date the enquiry which led to the registration of the case as that enquiry partook of the character of investigation.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Kotwal that the prosecution of the accused was barred by time under section 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes, Act, 1942. The section reads as under No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act or the rules made thereunder.

We have heard Mr. Kotwal on behalf of the, appellants and are of the opinion that there is numbermerit in the appeal.
